title: Introduction to Cost Accounting and Cost Classification
headline: Master the components of cost accounting, calculating break-even point and doing CVP analysis with this free course.
description: This free online course in cost accounting provides a comprehensive guide to the importance of financial management and the components of cost accounting. Learn about ways cost can be classified along with the functions of marginal cost. You will also learn how to calculate and analyse the break-even point using different relevant case studies.
courseDescription:
This course begins by introducing you to the important steps to consider in financial management as well as the different components of cost accounting. You will learn about the various ways cost can be classified, the components of cost-volume-profit (CVP) analysis, the different methods of calculating profit as well as contribution margin, and the importance of marginal cost in cost accounting.

It will also introduce you to the function as well as the objectives of CPV analysis in cost accounting, along with its assumptions. Learn about the different formulas for calculating profit and contribution margin in cost accounting, as well as how the CPV graph is plotted along with examples of how it applies to our daily lives.

Finally, the material introduces you to the function of the break-even (B/E) point as well as how it can be applied in accounting problems. It will teach you about the functions of sensitivity analysis and under which condition the cost-volume-profit assumption can be changed. Start this course now and improve your knowledge of the functions of make or buy decisions, shut down cost, joint product, as well as joint product cost allocation in cost accounting.

Start Course Now

• Learning Outcomes
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Discuss the concept of cost accounting and the types of cost in cost accounting.
    • Identify the different ways of classifying costs.
    • Differentiate between direct costs and indirect costs.
    • Explain cost volume profit analysis and the breakeven point.
    • Explain how graphs are plotted for a fixed cost, the variable cost, and semi-variable cost.
    • Analyze the formulas for calculating the profit equation and contribution margin.

  • Lesson Summary
    • The three important steps in financial accounting are the recording of every financial transaction, preparation of financial report or statement, and targeting external users. In cost accounting, however, the steps are recording of costs, analysis of costs, preparation of cost statements, and targeting internal users.
    • Cost accounting involves the recording, estimating, controlling and reporting of costs. The objectives of cost accounting include the ascertainment of cost, cost control, cost reduction, as well as assisting the management in decision making such as pricing, profit planning, and budgeting.
    • Costs can be classified in the following ways; by element, function, as direct or indirect, by controllability, normality, variability, and relevance.
    • The marginal cost is also known as the cost volume profit (CVP). It has the following components; fixed cost, variable costs, semi-variable costs, contribution margin, breakeven point, and the PV ratio.
    • Fixed costs are costs incurred for a particular period of time, within which certain output and turnover limits are not affected by the fluctuations in the levels of activity. Variable costs, on the other hand, is the type of cost that changes as the activity level changes.
    • The cost volume profit analysis takes into account the total fixed and variable cost, total sales revenue, and the desired profit vis-a-vis the sales volume. The CVP helps in the understanding the interaction among prices of products and the mix of product sold.
    • The formula for calculating profit is total sales minus total variable cost minus total fixed cost. Contribution margin is calculated by subtracting total variable cost from total revenue.
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Explain how breakeven point analysis can be applied in cost accounting.
    • Discuss the concept of sales mix and how to calculate the breakeven point of the sales mix.
    • Explain the concept of sensitivity analysis and its importance in cost accounting.
    • Explain how to calculate the profit volume ratio (PV) in cost accounting.
    • Discuss the decision making processes involved in product planning with concrete accounting problems.
    • Discuss the concepts of relevant versus sunk cost, and make or buy decision in cost accounting.

  • Relevant vs Sunk Cost

  • Relevant vs Sunk Cost

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary
    • The formula for calculating breakeven point is fixed cost divided by contribution per unit.
    • Decision making in cost analysis can be used for profit planning and product mix.
    • Relevant costs are not historical costs but future costs to be associated with different inputs and activities related to a particular business decision.
    • Not all variable costs are relevant and not all fixed costs are irrelevant. Fixed cost or variable cost that differs for various alternatives are relevant cost.
    • Sunk costs are all cost incurred or committed in the past that cannot be changed by any decision made now or in the future.  Sunk cost should not be considered in decision making.
    • Make or buy decision is the act of making a tactical choice between producing an item internally or buying it from outside suppliers.
    • In taking make and buy decision, the two factors to be considered are whether surplus capacity is available and the marginal cost.
    • The elements of make analysis include incremental inventory carrying cost,  direct labour cost, incremental factory overhead cost, delivered purchased material cost, incremental managerial cost, incremental purchasing cost, and incremental capital cost.
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Explain how to calculate the breakeven point using real-life case studies. 
    • Discuss how decisions are made based on the breakeven point analysis.
    • Analyze how to compute the breakeven point in accounting problems.
    • Explain how the calculation of the marginal cost helps in the projection of a company.
    • Discuss how projections for two different products are made in a company.

  • Shree Cements

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary
    • In this module, the breakeven point was calculated to make a decision for a school going on a picnic. This case study covered cost accounting and control.
    • Calculation of variable cost, fixed cost, semi-fixed cost, and total cost were covered using real-life accounting problems.
    • Short term decision making covering the marginal cost, cost volume profit as well as a breakeven point with practical examples were calculated in this module.
    • This module also covered how to make future projections for a company's product or different subsidiaries using Divya Aushadhi Ltd as a case study.
    •  The Divya Aushadhi case study also shed light on why variables change because of two factors as well as how to calculate operating cash profit.
    • Finally, the Shree cement case study discussed how the company's previous year's projection was used as data for projecting for the next year.
